webTitle: Co-op Bank saved Britannia Building Society from collapse, regulator says

fields.bodyText: Britannia Building Society would have collapsed if it had not been taken over by the Co-operative Bank, the Bank of England's chief regulator told MPs. Andrew Bailey said at the height of the financial crisis attention was diverted from Britannia's risky loan book by its merger with the Co-op in 2009. "Yes, it would have failed. The merger essentially took it out of the limelight and in that sense it achieved its objective," Bailey told the Treasury select committee. "Britannia was one of the building societies in 2008 and 2009 that was in trouble." He said Britannia would have been unable to gain funding in the markets because of worries about its commercial property loans and riskier residential mortgages. Lack of market funding was what almost destroyed Northern Rock and Royal Bank of Scotland. A bailout by the government would have also put extra strain on the Financial Services Compensation Scheme, which repays depositors at failed lenders. That, in turn, would have caused other building societies to fail because they could not have afforded to fund the scheme. The Co-op Bank and Britannia announced their merger in late 2008 and completed it in early 2009, hailing the creation of a "supermutual" that would act in its customers' interests while taking on the big banks. The combined bank was led by former Britannia boss Neville Richardson. Though regulators have criticised Britannia before, Bailey's remarks are the first time a regulator has said Britannia would have collapsed. From 2011 the combined bank attempted a takeover of more than 600 Lloyds Banking Group branches. That deal collapsed last April shortly before the Co-op Bank revealed a £1.5bn hole in its balance sheet. The crisis forced the Co-op Group to cede control of 70% of the bank to hedge funds and outside investors before the bank's former chairman Paul Flowers was embroiled in a drug scandal. Bailey said the Co-op's financial woes were mainly caused by Britannia's earlier expansion into lending it was not equipped to manage. He rejected Richardson's claims to MPs last year that the Co-op Bank was the source of most of the problems. MPs asked Bailey why, when he was in charge of bank regulation at the former Financial Services Authority [FSA}, he allowed the Co-op Bank to try to buy the Lloyds branches when he had told the bank it was short of capital. Bailey said it was not his job to run the bank and that if the Co-op had sorted out its finances and governance the deal might have worked. But he admitted the FSA did not have systems in place to run regular and thorough enough "stress tests" to spot the extent of the Co-op's problems. After spending lots of money the Bank of England will be able to do so later this year, he said. He also rejected former Co-op Bank executives' claims that the Bank of England changed its rules on capital, suddenly leaving the Co-op Bank with a gaping shortage. The bank already knew it had a £900m shortfall and had under-reported potential bad debts, Bailey said. Lord Levene, who was chairman of NBNK, which also tried to buy the Lloyds branches, told the committee last month that political interference had scuppered his potential bid. He said former Bank of England governor Lord King had told him NBNK was doomed to fail. Bailey said he had told King before his meeting with Levene in 2012 that there was "a lot of political interest in the transaction". Bailey also said the FSA took into account the government's wish for more competition in banking alongside its duty to ensure banks were "safe and sound" but he said there was no political pressure. Bailey said he told the Co-op Bank to tell Lloyds about his concerns about its capital position in 2011 and that the Co-op passed his views on. He said he was surprised that Sir Win Bischoff, Lloyds' chairman, had said he was never told about the Co-op's problems.

webTitle: Barclays condemned over £2.4bn bonuses

fields.bodyText: Barclays faced condemnation on Tuesday after announcing a 10% rise in bonus payouts despite a dramatic fall in profits and plans to cut 12,000 jobs this year. The bank's new boss, Antony Jenkins, came under intense pressure after being accused of failing on promises made only a year ago to clamp down on pay and change the culture of the bank after its £290m fine for rigging Libor. The TUC accused the bank of "sticking two fingers up to hard-pressed families across Britain", while the Unite union was furious at further cuts at the retail bank, which could harm customer service. But the harshest words came from the Institute of Directors, whose corporate governance director Roger Barker asked "for whom is this institution being run?" after the bank paid out £2.4bn in bonuses but just £860m in dividends to shareholders. The bank disputes that figure, but refused to say exactly how much it is paying out to shareholders, which has been complicated by last year's £5.8bn rights issue, forced upon Barclays by the Bank of England to boost its financial strength. The main investor body, the Association British of Insurers, refused to respond to Barker's accusation that investors were "supine" in failing to control pay at Barclays. The position of the bank's chair of remuneration committee Sir John Sutherland – appointed to the role only 18 months ago – was also questioned. Sunderland is entering his 10th year on the board, after which he is technically no longer deemed independent. The total bonus pay for 2013 is £2.4bn – up from £2.2bn a year ago. Within that, the investment bankers enjoyed bonuses of £1.6bn compared with £1.4bn a year ago, even though their division suffered a loss in the fourth quarter and its annual profits tumbled 37%. Profits across the group, which also includes high street banking, Barclaycard and operations in Africa, fell 32% to £5.2bn. On a statutory basis – including accounting quirks and other one-off items – the profits were higher, at £2.9bn. Frances O'Grady, general secretary of the TUC, said: "Barclays has stuck two fingers up to hard-pressed families across Britain by announcing another multibillion-pound bonus pool." Labour said its bonus tax should be reintroduced. Jenkins, who has waived his own £2.7m bonus, insisted he had the support of shareholders for the higher bonuses, which had to be paid because he had no control over market-led pay. He also insisted the bank was acting within the "spirit and letter" of the law by paying monthly "allowances" to key staff who might otherwise face pay cuts as a result of the new EU cap on bonuses, which will limit payouts next year to 100% of salary, or 200% if shareholders approve. "We employ people from Singapore to San Francisco. We compete in global markets for talent. If we are to act in the best interests of our shareholders we have to make sure we have the best people in the firm," Jenkins said. The average bonus per member of staff, across the bank, is £17,000, up from £15,600. However, the average payout in the investment banking operation is £60,100, up from £54,500 – including payouts to low level and administrative staff. The bonuses to the highest paid staff will be revealed next month when the bank publishes its annual report. Last year, it handed more than £1m to 428 of its bankers. Jenkins said 820 senior roles – or 10% – would be cut. He also disputed concerns about the impact of job cuts on customer service. Seven thousand of the 12,000 job cuts will be in the UK but not all in the high street. "The reason why we're doing this is not because we're trying to deliver poorer customer service, actually quite the reverse. Customers can now do their banking when its convenient to them, not … us. Technology allows [us] to reduce headcount," said Jenkins. There was no programme for branch closures, he said, but conceded the 1,700-strong network was changing. Vince Cable, the business secretary, said: "We need a responsible banking sector [that] rejects the bonus-fuelled culture of the past and puts the needs of consumers and businesses at the heart of what they do." Andrew Tyrie, chairman of the Treasury select committee, said Barclays' shareholders needed to ask if the pay was justified by the bank's returns to shareholders. Even the presentation to City analysts was dominated by questions about bonuses and the investment bank. "Analysts were "perplexed" and "disappointed" by the investment bank pay rises," said independent analyst Louise Cooper. A year ago, when Jenkins announced his plan to turn Barclays into the "go to" bank, the shares rose 9% to 327p. On Tuesday, they were the biggest fallers in the FTSE 100, ending nearly 4% lower at 264p. The dividend was held at 6.5p for the year.

webTitle: Janet Yellen says recovery in labor market 'far from complete'

fields.standfirst:
• Short-term jobless an ‘unusually large fraction of unemployed’
  • Yellen makes first Capitol Hill outing as Fed chair
  • Asset purchases ‘not on a preset course’, Yellen says
  • Read the latest blog summary here
  • Read our latest news story here
fields.body:
8.10pm GMT

Summary

We’re going to wrap up our live blog coverage of Janet Yellen’s first congressional hearing as Fed chair. If you are still hungry for more – good news! She’ll be back on Thursday, to testify before the Senate.

Yellen’s appearance was notable for its non-notability. She said asset purchasing will “likely” be tapered unless something changes; she said the jobs market is better but not great; she said the Fed will look to the unemployment and inflation rates in setting future interest rates policy.

Other tidbits included:

• Yellen said the CBO “has done important analysis” on the likely effects on the economy of the Affordable Care Act. “I think they’ve recognized that the impact of the act is likely to be complex. I think they’re still trying to figure out what all of the different channels are by which it will effect the economy,” she said.

• Yellen said she was “surprised that the jobs reports and the January pace of job creation was running under what I had anticipated, but we have to be very careful about jumping to conclusions about what those reports mean.” Bad weather may have been to blame, she said.

• Yellen said land prices are “remarkable” in the eyes of the Fed. “I think land prices have been going up at a remarkable rate even before [the stock market climb], and have caught our attention as an area that we would be concerned about valuations,” she said.

• Yellen acknowledged that including discouraged workers in the unemployment rate lifts it to around 13%, “a much broader measure of shortfall in our economy from what we would like to see.”

• Yellen’s prepared testimony is available on the committee web site. The Dow has floated upward over the course of the day, to reach about +1.37% with 50 minutes of trading to go.

Updated at 8.19pm GMT

7.40pm GMT

Yellen is done. The committee recesses for a floor vote. A panel of economists is to testify next:

  • Dr. John B. Taylor, Mary and Robert Raymond Professor of Economics, Stanford University
  • Dr. Mark A. Calabria, Director, Financial Regulation Studies, Cato Institute
  • Ms. Abby M. McCloskey, Director, Economic Policy, American Enterprise Institute
  • Dr. Donald Kohn, Senior Fellow, Economic Studies, Brookings Institution

7.33pm GMT

Yellen is asked about tax policy. Rep. Robert Pittenger wants her to admit that lowering taxes would boost consumer spending.

“Well, certainly,” she says.

They don’t get into government spending.

7.15pm GMT

Rep. Mick Mulvaney, Republican of South Carolina, is exploring the dynamics of a potential US debt default. He wants to know whether, in order to avoid default, the Treasury could prioritize the bills it pays after slamming into the debt ceiling.

“That’s a matter that is entirely up to the Treasury,” Yellen says. “That is not in the domain of the Federal Reserve... it is not up to us to develop a plan.”

Mulvaney asks whether the fed could create such a plan if asked to do so by the Treasury.

“I don’t know that we could do that,” Yellen says.

6.49pm GMT

Yellen says land prices are “remarkable” in the eyes of the Fed:

“I think land prices have been going up at a remarkable rate even before [the stock market climb], and have caught our attention as an area that we would be concerned about valuations.”

Updated at 6.52pm GMT

6.45pm GMT

Moore asks Yellen how the Fed can address income inequality.

“Our tool kit I’m afraid is more limited than what’s necessary to deal with these trends,” Yellen says. Bernanke used to say the same.

She says the Fed can help get a strong recovery going.

6.42pm GMT

Rep. Gwen Moore, Democrat of Wisconsin, thanks Yellen for testifying now coming up on four hours.

“I don’t remember the former chair indulging us in this way,” Moore says. “Maybe things will change after you’re here for a time or two.”

Updated at 6.43pm GMT

6.39pm GMT

They’re back. Rep. Bob Hurt, Republican of Virginia, said unemployment in his district, the 5th (south-central), has run as high as 25%.

He asks Yellen to talk about policies that can help community banks, not just the big guys.

“As a general philosophy, I don’t agree with one-size-fits-all,” Yellen says. “Community banks clearly do not pose the kind of systemic risk to financial stability that the larger banking organizations do.”

6.34pm GMT

We’re waiting for them to come back.

Updated at 6.35pm GMT

6.07pm GMT

The committee is taking a half-hour break.

6.02pm GMT

This line of questioning from Representative Posey has rendered Yellen speechless. Not because she is stumped. Except maybe by the extreme dazzlement of his leaps of logic and non sequitur.

Updated at 6.03pm GMT

6.00pm GMT

Yellen is still answering questions about auditing the Fed.

“I don’t believe that the Federal Reserve is in any way corrupt, and I believe the confidence of markets... would not be enhanced by that type of audit,” she says.

5.57pm GMT

Just two questions left before recess, Hensarling advises. Rep Bill Posey, REpublican of Florida, uses one of them to re-ask the Bachmann question about auditing the Fed.

Updated at 6.07pm GMT

5.56pm GMT

Yellen is asked by Rep. Emanuel Cleaver, Democrat of Missouri, about the U-6 unemployment rate, which takes into account discouraged workers who have left the tallied labor force.

The U-6 number is around 13%, Yellen says.

“That is a much broader measure of shortfall in our economy from what we would like to see. Certainly there are discouraged workers, those who are marginally attached. ... That’s a measure that is disproportionately elevated in comparison with the 6.6% or the U-3 unemployment rate.

5.50pm GMT

Rep. Stevan Pearce, Republican of New Mexico, invites Yellen to visit his district and take questions from seniors about interest rates at a town hall.

She thanks him for the invitation.

Updated at 5.51pm GMT

5.38pm GMT

Rep. Michele Bachmann, Republican of Minnesota, is up. Why do you oppose auditing the Fed, she asks Yellen.

“I strongly believe that the Federal Reserve should be audited...” Yellen says. “We are audited. We’re audited by the GAO... we have outside public accounting firms that audit the Fed... we publish our balance sheets weekly...”

But don’t interfere with monetary policy by bringing political pressures to bear, Yellen says.

Updated at 5.47pm GMT

5.33pm GMT

Tall order from Rep. David Scott, Democrat of Georgia:

“I want a yes-or-no answer. Will you lift employment up? ... We need more than just 0% interest rates.”

He does not sound like he will be satisfied unless Yellen vows personally to employ thousands of Americans. She does not vow to do that but reaffirms her general commitment to upholding the Fed’s dual mandate.

Updated at 5.35pm GMT

5.28pm GMT

No news is good news when you’re a central bank chair taking questions from Congress.

5.19pm GMT

Summary

Here’s a summary of where things stand:

• In her first Capitol Hill outing as chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, Janet Yellen said that a recovery in the jobs market was “far from complete” but the economy has made “substantial” improvement in the last four years.

• If economic developments are satisfactory, the Fed will “likely reduce” asset purchases, Yellen said, but the program is “not on a preset course” and could shift as new data comes to light. The next Fed meeting is next month.

• Markets reacted by moving lazily upward, with the Dow up .86% at midday.

• Yellen faced some mild freshman hazing from members of the committee, but nothing that affected her calm, methodical demeanor. Many members congratulated Yellen on her confirmation and praised her historic ascent as the first woman to lead the Fed.

5.12pm GMT

Yellen says the recovery has been slow, but there has been progress on unemployment:

“It certainly has been a slow recovery by standards of US history... but 7.8m jobs have been created since the trough of employment... in 2010... we’re not back to maximum employment [but] there has been substantial improvement.”

4.56pm GMT

It’s true, Yellen has more than once gone out of her way to disclaim the status of “panacea” for this or that economic policy.

And here are ten other things that are not panaceas.

4.51pm GMT

You can almost see Yellen’s Brooklyn accent in this AP photo:

4.44pm GMT

Yellen is asked about the CBO report finding that some people may leave the labor market as a result of the Affordable Care Act.

“CBO has done important analysis,” Yellen says. “I think they’ve recognized that the impact of the act is likely to be complex. I think they’re still trying to figure out what all of the different channels are by which it will effect the economy.”

4.38pm GMT

How’s Yellen doing so far? She’s been methodical, responsive, elusive, exact, polite, imprecise. Asked what the Fed will do, she points backward to what the Fed has done and to its explanations of why. Not saying too much. Not saying too little. Textbook stuff so far.

4.34pm GMT

“The Fed has almost become a deficit-enabler, in that you’re making it very easy to mask what the real cost of these deficits are,” Neugebauer says. He is equating asset purchases, and associated low interest rates, with an effort to hide federal deficit spending.

Yellen says the policy is motivated by unemployment and inflation benchmarks, “very important objectives that Congress has assigned to us,” and not by an attempt to hide the debt.

Neugebauer says Congress didn’t pass a bill for quantitative easing. That was a Fed choice. “That very choice has really impacted the markets, and I believe is enabling these deficits to continue,” he says.

He’s arguing that balancing the budget should be an overriding short-term economic goal. The argument, which is likely to outlive us all, has been made elsewhere, and rebutted, and made again, and rebutted.

Five-minute recess.

Updated at 4.40pm GMT

4.24pm GMT

Rep. Randy Neugebauer, Republican of Texas, asks whether the deficit hurts economic growth.

Yellen says unsustainable long-term deficits have a negative effect of the economy. But it’s a chicken-and-egg deal, because deficits are also a reflection of economic weakness, she says.

“I’m going to take that as a yes,” Neugebauer says.

4.17pm GMT

How many hours a week would you consider a part-time job? The president’s defined it as 29 hours and above. Yellen says the Fed definition is under 35 hours. The president uses a Bureau of Labor Statistics definition, she says. An interesting moment because Yellen paused to confer with aides.

Updated at 4.22pm GMT

4.15pm GMT

Rep. Shelley Moore Capito of West Virginia has just praised Yellen for the clarity of her answers. Others watching are impressed with the questions. Is it a golden new sunrise for US economics talk?

4.09pm GMT

Rep Carolyn Maloney asks whether January’s weak jobs report has caused the Fed to consider slowing the “taper” – its plan to decrease asset purchases.

“I was surprised that the jobs reports and the January pace of job creation was running under what I had anticipated, but we have to be very careful about jumping to conclusions about what those reports mean,” Yellen says.

She says unseasonably cold temperatures may have played a role. “I think it’s important for us to take our time to assess just what our significance of this is,” in the lead-up to the Fed meeting in March, she says.

“What would cause the committee to consider a pause is a notable change in the outlook,” she says.

4.03pm GMT

Chairman Hensarling began the hearing by referring Yellen to the cameras all around her and warning that she was in the big time now. But if there’s any secret to how these hearing things work, it does not seem hidden to her:

3.58pm GMT

Rep. Bill Huizenga, Republican of Michigan, asks whether the US shouldn’t be concerned about hurting other economies by slowing its asset purchases program. If US bond rates lift, the thinking goes, investors may leave foreign shores for the lure of strengthening Treasury yields.

Yellen acknowledges that Fed policy has foreign ramifications, but she does not leave much room for the impact on foreign economies to figure into this category of Fed decisions. “We have tried to be as clear as we possibly can” in our asset purchases policy, Yellen says.

“It’s quite clear at the outset that as our recovery advanced... we would wind down our asset purchases.”

3.50pm GMT

3.48pm GMT

How are the markets reacting? Somewhere between “meh” and “zzz”, says Guardian US business correspondent Dominic Rushe (@dominicru).

There’s minimal movement, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 83.00, or 0.53%.

3.46pm GMT

Rep. Waters comes out as “a supporter of quantitative easing.” She asks Yellen to summarize how the policy worked.

Yellen says the Fed succeeded in pushing down longer-term interest rates by buying bonds and mortgage-backed securities. “As mortgage rates fell to historically low levels, we ... have seen a very meaningful increase in house prices, and I think that’s improved the security of a very large number of households.” She says low rates have also boosted spending in manufacturing sectors such as automobiles. And, the unemployment rate is down 1.5%.

3.43pm GMT

Hensarling asks a rather condescending question: “Are you a sensible central banker, and if not, when will you become one?”

Yellen does not seem bothered: “Mr. congressman, I believe that I am one... The conditions facing the economy are extremely unusual.”

3.41pm GMT

Hensarling has a first question. He uses a Wall Street Journal editorial to accuse the Fed of “improvisation”.

Yellen says when the federal funds rate functionally hit zero, the Fed needed to turn to novel tools, including forward guidance.

Hensarling accuses the Fed of ignoring the federal funds rate threshold of zero by turning to other policies. He interrupts Yellen a couple times. “There’s one thing the Fed says. There’s other things the market may here,” he says.

3.38pm GMT

Guardian US finance and economics editor Heidi Moore grabs the scene:

3.37pm GMT

Guardian business correspondent Dominic Rushe picks up on a tic in the statements so far by Republican members, who used air quotes to signal their skepticism of any so-called economic facts:

3.33pm GMT

If developments in the unemployment and inflation rates are satisfactory, the Fed will “likely reduce” asset purchases, although the purchases are “not on a preset course,” Yellen says, as expected:

If incoming information broadly supports the Committee’s expectation of ongoing improvement in labor market conditions and inflation moving back toward its longer-run objective, the Committee will likely reduce the pace of asset purchases in further measured steps at future meetings. That said, purchases are not on a preset course, and the Committee’s decisions about their pace will remain contingent on its outlook for the labor market and inflation as well as its assessment of the likely efficacy and costs of such purchases.

3.31pm GMT

“Economic activity and employment will expand at a moderate rate in this year and the next” and inflation will move back toward 2%,” Yellen says.

“I expect a great deal of continuity in the [Fed’s] approach to monetary policy,” she says. The Fed’s two-part goal, she says, will continue to be maximum employment and price stability.

Yellen’s prepared testimony is available on the committee web site.

webTitle: Yellen surprised by jobs report and admits US recovery 'far from complete'

fields.standfirst: New chair of the Federal Reserve faced members of Congress for the first time since taking over from Ben Bernanke
fields.body:
The US economic recovery is “far from complete,” new Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen told lawmakers Tuesday.

Testifying in her first congressional appearance since she became the central bank’s first chairwoman, Yellen said Fed policy was likely to closely follow the course set out by her predecessor, Ben Bernanke. “I served on the committee as we formulated our current policy strategy and I strongly support that strategy,” she said.

Yellen took over from Bernanke just as the recovery in the jobs market appears to have stalled. In January, the US added just 113,000 new jobs, up from an even more disappointing 75,000 in December. Both figures were well below economists’ forecasts. Last year, the economy added an average of 194,000 jobs per month.

“I was surprised that the jobs reports in December and January, the pace of job creation, was running under what I had anticipated. But we have to be very careful not to jump to conclusions in interpreting what those reports mean,” she said. She said the extremely cold winter may have affected the numbers.

Yellen declined to give any specifics about whether or not the Fed would slow the pace of cuts it is making to its now $65bn-a-month quantitative easing (QE) stimulus program.

Yellen said the Fed “will likely reduce the pace of asset purchases in further measured steps at future meetings.” But she added that the bond-buying program was “not on a pre-set course”.

She said a “notable change in the outlook,” could cause the Fed to pause in the pace of its cuts.

Yellen, an expert on the labour markets, appears to be moving away from the Fed’s previous commitment to raise interest rates above zero once the unemployment rate his 6.5%.

Last month the jobless rate hit 6.6%, but the number of long-term unemployed remains worryingly high. And specific demographic groups still have high rates of unemployment – in January, the unemployment rate for teenagers was 20.7%; for African Americans, it was 12.1%, and for Hispanics, 8.4%. Yellen also pointed to the large number of people who are working part-time but would prefer to have full-time jobs as a sign of weakness in the job market.

“These observations underscore the importance of considering more than the unemployment rate when evaluating the condition of the US labour market,” she said.

The testimony came as the US appears to have avoided another fight over its federal government’s debt limit. House speaker John Boehner, a Republican, on Tuesday scrapped plans to link a debt-limit increase to concessions that would have triggered a standoff with Democrats. The House is now expected to make a “clean” vote Wednesday on an increase in the nation’s borrowing limit. It would be the first unconditional vote to raise the debt limit since Boehner became House speaker in January 2011.

Yellen said the Fed had yet to see any impact from the other economic black cloud now worrying economists – the recent turmoil in the emerging markets. “We have been watching closely the recent volatility in global financial markets. Our sense is that at this stage these developments do not pose a substantial risk to the US economic outlook,” she said.

webTitle: FTSE flies high on Yellen testimony, with retailers and miners leading the way

fields.standfirst: Mining shares helped by rising metal prices as buoyant January sales lift high street
fields.body:
Retailers and mining shares were in the spotlight as leading shares moved sharply higher.

High street businesses, particularly non-food retailers, benefited from a strong January performance as evidenced by the latest British Retail Consortium report. Analysts at Jefferies said:

The BRC reported strong January retail sales growth of 5.4% with like for like increases of 3.9% (versus 2.8% and 1.2% respectively in 2013). We estimate a very contrasting like for like development in food (where we calculate declines of 1.9%) and in non-food. In the latter we calculate like for like growth of close to 10%.
Non-food housing related items seem to be booming, with the qualitative commentary suggesting double-digit like for like growth for large ticket items typically linked to lifting housing transactions (bedroom furniture, sofas, white goods, TVs etc). Clothing was also solid, but likely aided by a very soft comparable (with early sales hit in 2013 by the very cold weather).

So Marks & Spencer added 15.3p to 485.6p, Kingfisher climbed 11.7p to 376.8p, Debenhams rose 3.8p to 77.70, Home Retail was 9.6p higher at 190.4p and Sports Direct International ended up 23p at 708p. JD Sports Fashion bucked the trend, down 63p at £14.17.

And supermarkets fell back after Kantar Worldpanel data showed poor sales performances from Tesco, down 5p at 318.7p, and Morrisons, 3.1p lower at 237.2p, and only marginal growth at J Sainsbury, down 7.3p at 348.9p. Morrisons and Tesco saw sales fall by 2.5% and 0.4% in the 12 weeks to 2 February, as discounters continued to gain market share.

Overall, though, the FTSE 100 rose 81.11 points or 1.23% to 6672.66 as markets warmed to the first testimony from Janet Yellen as chair of the US Federal Reserve, in which she saw continued recovery in the US economy and said the trimming of the central bank's bond buying programme would continue depending on the economic data. Michael Hewson, chief market analyst at CMC Markets UK, said:

European markets have made broad based gains today after the latest testimony from new Fed chair Janet Yellen emphasised the importance of continuity in the implementation of US monetary policy. She emphasised that future tapering was very much data dependant and that emerging market volatility was not a concern given that these markets were perceived to be much better positioned to manage the current uncertainty than they were at the end of the 1990's.

News that the Kazakh central bank would allow the country's currency, the tenge, to devalue by around 19% from Monday's level has boosted miner Kazakhmys by more than a quarter. Its shares soared 31.4p to 208.4p, making it the biggest riser in the FTSE 250, as the central bank set a new target of 185 tenge a dollar, compared to 156 on Monday.

But analysts at Liberum said the devaluation benefits for Kazakhmys would be limited:

Whilst there are obvious short-term benefits to a tenge devaluation for a labour heavy workforce – the move in and of itself won't be altering our hold recommendation. As was seen with the last major tenge devaluation in 2009, the devaluation in the currency resulted in a subsequent sharp inflation spike from about 9 months post-devaluation – 12 months after the devaluation inflation was running close to 50%, completely eroding any initial benefit of the devaluation.

Other mining shares were also stronger. With gold continuing to move higher, precious metals miner Fresnillo added 49p to p while Randgold Resources rose 175p to £47.05.

Meanwhile iron ore specialist Ferrexpo was 6.9p better at 165.4p.

Glencore Xstrata added 6.8p to 332.85p after it beat forecasts with a 25% rise in annual copper production and gains in coal output. Killik and Co said:

Although the direction of commodity prices – particularly copper and coal – will continue to exert an important influence on the group's profitability, we believe there are a number of factors that set Glencore Xstrata apart from its rivals. Firstly, the group will benefit from the synergies from the merger [of Glencore and Xstrata], which we believe could be much higher than the $2bn disclosed today. Secondly, by being present at each stage of the commodities chain, the group has superior market insight and access to opportunities, particularly in emerging pinch points in the commodities chain. Finally, with around a quarter of the stock held by management, the interests of shareholders are clearly aligned. We remain positive on the shares.

But Barclays slumped 10.3p to 264.7p after it unveiled its full figures after Monday's partial declaration.

RSA Insurance continued to fall on concerns about the cost of the floods, down another 3.4p at 99.10p. But Prudential put on 31p to £13.09 after a buy note from Beaufort Research:

Through the financial and investment services it provides in Asia, the US and the UK, Prudential is a natural play on global economic recovery, the associated rise in disposable income and growing demand for its products. Compared with the more developed markets for financial services elsewhere, demand for its services is growing rapidly in Asia with operating profit expected to nearly double over the five years to 2017. Growth in the US is strong on the back of the economic recovery there while activity in the UK is expected to gain a boost from the introduction in April 2014 of pension auto-enrolment. The Prudential share price has risen six-fold since the financial crisis low in March 2009 but the underlying earnings growth potential remains intact. Consequently, the 12 % fall in price in the recent market sell-off created an attractive opportunity to buy the shares.

Elsewhere Babcock International jumped 53p to £13.95 after a positive trading update.

The engineering support services group said it had traded well in the third quarter following a strong first half, with the economic climate continuing to support outsourcing. It said its financial performance was in line with expectations despite weakness in the South African rand, and its £11.5bn order book gave it good future visibility.

It made a point of listing its recent acquisitions, prompting the City to speculate that more could be on the way.

Among the mid-caps Icap, the inter-dealer broker, added 15.5p to 414.5p after an upgrade from Goldman Sachs, which moved from sell to neutral. The bank said:

Shares in Icap have recently underperformed peers in the diversified financial sector as volume weakness has weighed on investor expectations. Since adding to the sell List on January 10, 2014, Icap shares have fallen by 13.1% versus a 1.4% decline for the FTSE World Europe index and an average 0.8% decline in the other stocks in our diversified financial coverage. After recent weakness in the shares there is insufficient downside to our 12-month price target relative to our coverage and we therefore upgrade Icap. Our 2014 earnings per share forecast remains 3% below Reuters consensus.

Imagination Technologies rose 12.4p to 184.3p after positive news on its relationship with semiconductor group MediaTek.

MediaTek had linked up with rival Arm, which led to concerns among Imagination investors that the company could lose business with the US group. But MediaTek has announced a new smartphone technology using Imagination's graphics intellectual property.

Finally drug delivery company Skyepharma added 13p or 7% to 193.5p following the launch of its asthma treatment flutiform in France this week.

Secondly, by being present at each stage of the commodities chain, the group has superior market insight and access to opportunities, particularly in emerging pinch points in the commodities chain. Finally, with around a quarter of the stock held by management, the interests of shareholders are clearly aligned. We remain positive on the shares. But Barclays slumped 10.3p to 264.7p after it unveiled its full figures after Monday's partial declaration. RSA Insurance continued to fall on concerns about the cost of the floods, down another 3.4p at 99.10p. But Prudential put on 31p to £13.09 after a buy note from Beaufort Research: Through the financial and investment services it provides in Asia, the US and the UK, Prudential is a natural play on global economic recovery, the associated rise in disposable income and growing demand for its products. Compared with the more developed markets for financial services elsewhere, demand for its services is growing rapidly in Asia with operating profit expected to nearly double over the five years to 2017. Growth in the US is strong on the back of the economic recovery there while activity in the UK is expected to gain a boost from the introduction in April 2014 of pension auto-enrolment. The Prudential share price has risen six-fold since the financial crisis low in March 2009 but the underlying earnings growth potential remains intact. Consequently, the 12 % fall in price in the recent market sell-off created an attractive opportunity to buy the shares. Elsewhere Babcock International jumped 53p to £13.95 after a positive trading update. The engineering support services group said it had traded well in the third quarter following a strong first half, with the economic climate continuing to support outsourcing. It said its financial performance was in line with expectations despite weakness in the South African rand, and its £11.5bn order book gave it good future visibility. It made a point of listing its recent acquisitions, prompting the City to speculate that more could be on the way. Among the mid-caps Icap, the inter-dealer broker, added 15.5p to 414.5p after an upgrade from Goldman Sachs, which moved from sell to neutral. The bank said: Shares in Icap have recently underperformed peers in the diversified financial sector as volume weakness has weighed on investor expectations. Since adding to the sell List on January 10, 2014, Icap shares have fallen by 13.1% versus a 1.4% decline for the FTSE World Europe index and an average 0.8% decline in the other stocks in our diversified financial coverage. After recent weakness in the shares there is insufficient downside to our 12-month price target relative to our coverage and we therefore upgrade Icap. MediaTek had linked up with rival Arm, which led to concerns among Imagination investors that the company could lose business with the US group. But MediaTek has announced a new smartphone technology using Imagination's graphics intellectual property. webTitle: Selvedge job: jeans company helps Welsh town get back in its stride

fields.standfirst: Hiut Denim founders hope to employ Cardigan workers who lost their jobs when M&S moved jeans production to Morocco
fields.body:
Elin Evans angles the lamp over her sewing machine to shine a light on to the dark indigo cloth. The machinist's needle is poised over the Hiut Denim jeans, then a rapid burst of click-clacking leaves a perfect line of golden stitches around the fly.

The precision of the work is the hallmark of someone who has been making jeans for almost 30 years. However, this skill would probably have been lost without Hiut Denim, which was set up two years ago in Cardigan, a small market town in west Wales.

The company makes high-end jeans, costing up to £230 for a pair of selvedge denim, and sells them direct to customers through its website. It is part of a new breed of smaller British manufacturers that are eschewing traditional routes to market and embracing the benefits of the web. Hiut is the sort of operation that George Osborne evoked in his 2011 budget speech when he envisaged a "march of the makers" who would bolster Britain's fragile finances and rebalance the economy.

The jeans-maker was launched by David Hieatt, a former Saatchi advertising copywriter, and his wife, Clare, who together had already founded another Cardigan-based clothing brand, Howies.

The creation of Hiut Denim is rooted in the history of Cardigan. The town was once home to the biggest jeans factory in Britain, employing 400 in a town of 4,000 people. Dewhirst Ladieswear made jeans for Marks & Spencer until it closed the Cardigan operation and moved production to Morocco in November 2002.

Evans says the shutdown was "like a bereavement". It ripped the heart out of the town and dumped about 10% of the population on the dole overnight. But Hieatt recognised that the skills remained even though the factory was gone. "Even the postman who picks up our parcels at the end of the day used to cut jeans for 20 years," he says. "Like humans, towns can lose confidence. Cardigan lost some of its mojo when Dewhirst closed. It was world-class at making jeans one day, and the next day it was gone. They [staff] have got a second chance, myself and Clare have got a second chance and so has the town."

The Hieatts, who are Welsh, started Howies as a T-shirt-making operation in their London home in 1995. It grew, and they moved it to Cardigan in 2001.

But rapid growth blew a hole in the brand's finances and they were eventually forced to sell the business to Timberland, an American group, in 2006. Three years later, the husband and wife team left the business after clashing with the Timberland hierarchy about the direction of Howies. "I made mistakes [with Howies]," Hieatt admits. "So there is an element of unfinished business. It was a good apprenticeship because we wouldn't know how to build this now. I have to prove to myself that this time I can get it right."

Hiut – a combination of the first two letters of his surname and "utility" – started making jeans in Cardigan two years ago with five people, including staff from the old Dewhirst factory. The operation now has 10 employees – including four "grand masters", as Hieatt likes to call the machinists – because of their combined experience of more than 100 years.

He believes he can create a world-beating jeans brand from this part of west Wales to take on the likes of Nudie and Dr Denim. The next big step on that road will be to design a perfect pair of jeans for women. Hieatt is confident the brand can carve out a niche in the women's market and has just signed up one of only three mills in the world that can supply X Fit denim. This material comprises strands of crimped polyester wrapped in cotton, which enables the soft cloth to stretch in all directions without losing shape.

"We want to launch a women's X Fit jean in April and we will invite all the shops down here for it," he says.

If Hiut can crack the women's market, Hieatt will probably need a bigger factory. "I want to get those 390 other people their jobs back," he says.

Conventional wisdom suggests the company would stand a better chance of success by moving production to Asia, where labour is cheaper. But Hieatt reckons the internet has helped level the playing field. He scampers off into his whitewashed office to grab a laptop. The screen shows two images of crowds outside the Vatican in Rome to greet a new pope. One picture dates from 2005; the other from 2013. "In the first one, from 2005, you are lucky if you can spot two people holding mobile phones," he says. "In the second one, from last year, you are lucky if you can spot two people without mobile phones."

It demonstrates why high streets have become wastelands of empty stores – smartphones are portable shopping centres that have transformed the way people shop. "I can't think of anything that the internet is not changing in some way. It is making the march of the makers more doable," he says. "That's why I love those pictures. Stories travel for free now and they travel fast."

Social media has played a huge part in helping Hiut reach denim geeks in the hipster hotspots of London, New York and Tokyo. In its short life, the company has gained influential devotees, including "Taffia" Welsh rock royalty such as the Manic Street Preachers, Gruff Rhys from Super Furry Animals and Cate le Bon. Other converts to the brand include ageing punks the Stranglers, and Ant and Dec, who wore the Welsh company's jeans during the latest series of I'm a Celebrity. The TV presenters also gave the jeans-maker an unexpected boost by tweeting their denim allegiance to their 3.2 million followers.

The plug was invaluable, Hieatt says: "Celebrities have an incredible power, and when your marketing budget is as big as your coffee budget it's great because we couldn't afford to reach those people by traditional means."

If building a global denim brand from rural west Wales seems ambitious, Hieatt's next project is even more so. Four years ago, he thought about launching a startup school for budding entrepreneurs. He couldn't figure out the business model, so for a while nothing happened. He then read about Y Combinator, the US fund created by four computer programmers and venture capitalists that provides seed capital.

The fund takes a small stake in fledgling firms in return for 12 weeks of some of the best mentoring and business advice on the planet. It has funded successful technology companies such as Dropbox, Scribd and Reddit.

"This got me thinking 'why not do our own startup school in Cardigan?'" says Hieatt. "We pay people £10,000 to come along and we take a 7% stake. At the end of the 12-week course, we get all the money men here and the companies can pitch for funding."

To get the Dragons Den-style school up and running, Hieatt must first raise £4m. He hopes the financial regulator will approve the venture within the next few weeks. This will give him the green light to contact financial backers.

Why is this project so important to him? Hieatt pauses, then recalls a story about how Jack Lemmon inspired a teenage Kevin Spacey after seeing the younger actor in a youth theatre show and taking the time to give him some advice. "Lemmon later told him it was important to send the elevator back down for those starting out on the ground floor."

webTitle: European markets welcome Yellen's testimony - as it happened

fields.standfirst:
• Yellen signals continuity in monetary policy
  • European and Asian stocks rise as investors wait for Yellen’s testimony on Capitol Hill
  • Barclays increase banker bonuses amid falling profits and job cuts
  • Airbus A350 jet makes public debut in Singapore
fields.body:
4.45pm GMT

European markets lifted by Yellen comments

Buoyant ahead of Janet Yellen’s first testimony as chair of the US Federal Reserves, markets continued to gain ground during the course of her speech. Investors were buoyed by Yellen saying the Fed’s bond buying programme would continue to be trimmed, depending on future economic data. She seemed in no hurry to disrupt the path the Fed was taking, while showing willingness to be adaptable as circumstances changed. All this pushed markets sharply higher on the day:

• The FTSE 100 finished 81.11 points or 1.23% better at 6672.66, its high for the day

• Germany’s Dax added 1.83% to 9460.14

• France’s Cac closed 0.96% higher at 4278.00

• Italy’s FTSE MIB added 1.04% to 19,887.39

• Spain’s Ibex ended 1.09% higher at 10,091.2

The Dow Jones Industrial Average is currently 0.86% or 136 points higher.

And with that, I’ll close this blog down for the evening. Thanks for the comments and we’ll be back tomorrow when the Bank of England’s forward guidance will be in the spotlight.

Meanwhile, full coverage of Janet Yellen’s testimony continues in our US live blog here.

4.27pm GMT

The Bank of England is looking at allegations its officials endorsed sharing of information between traders in the foreign exchange market, the central bank’s deputy governor told MPs. My colleague Sean Farrell, who following the select committee, writes:

The inquiry will examine claims that at a meeting between Bank officials and senior currency traders last April the officials said it was permissible for traders in different banks to share information about clients’ positions ahead of the setting of a benchmark rate in the foreign exchange market.

Andrew Bailey told the Treasury select committee: “The governors of the Bank have taken the claims about the meeting with the Bank’s officials extremely seriously since we first heard about these allegations. Just so you know, we first heard about them in October.

“The governors immediately initiated a full review into it led by the Bank of England’s legal counsel but also supported by external legal counsel and also in close collaboration with the FCA (financial conduct authority).

The full story is here:

Bank of England launches inquiry into forex manipulation claims

4.00pm GMT

Yellen is answering questions now, and her testimony so far seems to be pleasing the markets. On Wall Street the Dow Jones Industrial Average is up around 70 points or 0.45% while the FTSE 100 has added nearly 60 points or 0.9%. Capital Spreads said:

A typically dovish stance from Janet Yellen’s first testimony this afternoon has buoyed the markets just as a smidgeon of profit taking was starting to permeate risky assets. The short-term trend is certainly positive for the bulls who have not enjoyed a good start to the year, but as fears surrounding emerging markets and the recovery start to reduce, the appetite for risk will push markets higher. Yellen’s view maintained that emerging markets posed less of a threat to the US economy than many had suggested, so all that investors now need is for the economic data to pick up and then the countdown to fresh all time highs can begin.

3.42pm GMT

Away from Janet Yellen and back to the Anglo Irish trial.

Another of of the 16 people alleged to have been unlawfully given financial assistance by three ex directors of the Anglo Irish Bank has told a Dublin court that the now defunct institution told him Ireland’s Financial Regulator had back their multi million euro loan scheme. Henry McDonald in Dublin writes:

Property developer Joe O’Reilly told the trial of the three bankers that he too had been assured that a leading law firm as well as the Financial Regulator had no problem with the loans aimed at buying shares in the bank.

O’Reilly said that one of the defendants in the case, Patrick Whelan flew down with Anglo Irish chief executive David Drumm (who is not on trial) to meet him on holiday in Faro, Portugal in July 2008.

He told the court that Drumm informed him “that had had legal advice from MOP (law firm Matheson Ormsby Prentice), senior counsel, and Morgan Stanley and that the financial regulator was on board” in relation to the deal.

The Anglo Irish bosses were attempting to persuade O’Reilly to take a multi-million euro loan in order to buy 10 million shares in the bank.

The accused - Whelan, William McAteer and Sean Fitzpatrick - have all pleaded not guilty to the charges of unlawfully providing finance to 16 individuals. The case continues.

3.26pm GMT

Back in Washington, after a bit of adjusting of the microphone, Janet Yellen has begun her first testimony, and is presenting her prepared remarks released earlier.

A reminder - our live blog is here and the live TV feed is here.

Updated at 3.31pm GMT

3.19pm GMT

Here’s a mea culpa from the OECD regarding its errors in forecasting global economic growth. My colleague Angela Monaghan writes:

A failure to spot the severity of the eurozone crisis and the impact of the meltdown of the global banking system led to consistent forecasting errors in recent years, the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development admitted on Tuesday.

The Paris-based organisation said it repeatedly overestimated growth prospects for countries around the world between 2007 and 2012. The OECD revised down forecasts at the onset of the financial crisis, but by an insufficient degree, it said.

“Forecasts were revised down consistently and very rapidly when the financial crisis erupted, but growth outturns nonetheless still proved substantially weaker than had been projected,” it said in a paper exploring its forecasting record in recent years.

The biggest forecasting errors were made when looking at the prospects for the next year, rather than the current year.

The full story is here:

OECD admits overstating growth forecasts amid eurozone crisis and global crash

3.07pm GMT

A live feed of Yellen’s testimony is here.

Updated at 3.13pm GMT

3.01pm GMT

My colleague Tom McCarthy in the US will be live blogging Yellen’s full testimony here:

Janet Yellen testifies to Congress in first outing as Federal Reserve chief

2.59pm GMT

Kathleen Brooks at Forex.com said people should not expect any major changes from Yellen immediately:

The only tweaks she may make are to forward guidance, she mentioned that the unemployment rate is not a complete indicator of labour market strength, thus the economic threshold could be changed or its scope widened to include a broader measure of the labour market that may not be as rosy as the unemployment rate suggests. However, it does not appear that a decision has been taken on this as yet.

As we expected, Yellen firmly reiterated that rates will stay low for a long time, however the market has ignored this message and Treasury yields are above 2.7% on the back of her comments. Thus, Yellen and co. will have to work harder to get the message through about rates if they want to keep yields low in the coming months.

Meanwhile Peter Spence of City AM has spotted what he thinks could be the Fed’s new forward guidance:

In her written testimony Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen said that “the number of people who are working part time but would prefer a full-time job remains very high.”

That’s an almost explicit mention of “U6” - one of the Bureau of Labor Statistics’ measures of unemployment. The headline rate is “U3”.

U6 captures all of that included in U3, along with “discouraged workers” (those who’ve stopped looking for work), “marginally attached” or “loosely attached workers “(who would like to work have not looked recently), and part-time workers who want to work full-time, but can’t for economic reasons.

While the Fed’s U3 unemployment threshold is set at 6.5 per cent, that might be roughly equivalent to 11.5 per cent unemployment as measured by U6.

2.23pm GMT

Ahead of Yellen’s appearance, hawkish Fed member Charles Plosser - a voting member this year but not last - has said assessing the US economy’s performance has become more difficult given the recent low temperatures and heavy snowfall. In a speech at the University of Delaware he said:

I suspect it may be another couple of months before we have a better read on the economy.

He repeated his belief that the Fed should move more quickly to cut back its bond buying programme, calling it “neither helpful nor essential.”

Even with the weak jobs reports in the past couple of months, he said there had been a significant improvement in labor market conditions, such that the criteria for ending the Fed’s economic stimulus had been met.

Yellen, of course, has just said crossing the 6.5% unemployment rate threshold would not automatically mean raising interest rates:

[It] will instead indicate only that it had become appropriate for the committee to consider whether the broader economic outlook would justify such an increase.

Updated at 2.35pm GMT

2.12pm GMT

The dollar should be bolstered by Yellen’s remarks, according to Gautam Batra, managing director and investment strategist at Signia Wealth:

Janet Yellen re-affirmed that the Fed will continue to gradually reduce monetary stimulus. Her refusal to highlight recent weakness in economic data is a clear indication that the Fed has changed its view regarding the efficacy of further asset purchases. Fed policy is now subject to the whim of financial markets.

Fixed income investors should be concerned and reduce duration in portfolios as interest rates rise from these unnaturally low levels. The US dollar should be bolstered by rising US yields.

And behold:

2.05pm GMT

Another $10bn trimming of the Federal Reserve’s bond buying programme could come in March, according to Rob Carnell at ING. In his initial reaction to Janet Yellen’s prepared testimony, he said:

Janet Yellen’s semi-annual monetary report to the Congress (her first official address as chair of the FOMC) was a relatively concise report. But it was also a fairly upbeat one. Despite some volatility in the data releases of late, Yellen seems to share our view that the US economy remains in acceleration mode – citing the pick-up in GDP growth rates during 2013 and also the improvements in the labour market – rather than focussing on recent payrolls disappointments.

Still, it was not all good news, and Yellen noted her unhappiness with high rates of long term unemployment and labour force disaffection and drop out.

It does look as if the old 6.5% unemployment rate forward guidance threshold is on its way out – which is only reasonable, given that the current unemployment rate is already 6.6%. Yellen talks instead about a “broad range of measures of labor market conditions, indicators of inflation pressures, and inflation expectations”. With this renewed emphasis on inflation (not currently a threat to policy rates) Yellen is perhaps trying to establish some early hawkish credentials – in contrast to her perception as a dove.

But then Yellen was also clear that she represented “continuity” in terms of policy – given her key role in formulating Fed communications strategy and their so-called “optimal monetary policy” approach. As such, this sounds like she does not anticipate deviating from the $10bn taper per meeting that was announced in December, and repeated at the January FOMC meeting. A further $10bn taper in March seems probable, especially as Yellen did not think that the current volatility in Emerging Markets yet posed a substantial risk to the US economy.

1.37pm GMT

The US Federal Reserve has released the text of Janet Yellen’s testimony to lawmakers - due to be delivered at 3pm GMT.

The full statement is available here, but I’ve culled some of the most striking lines.

The economic recovery gained greater traction in the second half of last year.

The unemployment rate is still well above levels that Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) participants estimate is consistent with maximum sustainable employment. Those out of a job for more than six months continue to make up an unusually large fraction of the unemployed, and the number of people who are working part time but would prefer a full-time job remains very high. These observations underscore the importance of considering more than the unemployment rate when evaluating the condition of the U.S. labor market.

I expect a great deal of continuity in the FOMC’s approach to monetary policy. I served on the Committee as we formulated our current policy strategy and I strongly support that strategy, which is designed to fulfill the Federal Reserve’s statutory mandate of maximum employment and price stability.

The Committee has emphasized that a highly accommodative policy will remain appropriate for a considerable time after asset purchases end.

In the near term, we expect to finalize the rules implementing enhanced prudential standards mandated by section 165 of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act. We also are working to finalize the proposed rule strengthening the leverage ratio standards for U.S.-based, systemically important global banks.

Since the financial crisis and the depths of the recession, substantial progress has been made in restoring the economy to health and in strengthening the financial system. Still, there is more to do. Too many Americans remain unemployed, inflation remains below our longer-run objective, and the work of making the financial system more robust has not yet been completed.

And with that, I’m handing over to my colleague Nick Fletcher.

Updated at 2.02pm GMT

1.35pm GMT

Breaking news: Federal Reserve chief Yellen says US jobs recovery far from complete

  • Recent global markets volatility does not pose substantial risks to US economic outlook - Yellen
  • Yellen expects “great deal of continuity” on US monetary policy
  • Yellen says committed to helping economy return to full employment and ensuring inflation not persistently above or below 2%

Updated at 1.35pm GMT

1.25pm GMT

Straight from Dublin, the latest from the Anglo Irish trial of three former bank executives blamed for Ireland’s banking crisis.

In a complex and controversial case, a trio of disgraced bank executives at Anglo Irish Bank – Sean FitzPatrick, Pat Whelan and William McAteer – are facing charges of unlawfully providing financial assistance to individuals for the purpose of buying shares in Anglo Irish Bank in 2008.

Henry McDonald in Dublin has the latest developments.

The son of Ireland’s one-time richest man has admitted in court that he had “scant knowledge” of the deal his father made to buy shares in the Anglo Irish Bank but accepted that his signatures were on the documents to seal the agreement.

Sean Quinn junior told the trial of three Anglo Irish Bank executives in Dublin today that most of the signatures on the papers that secured the deal were his.

His father was spending hundreds of millions of euros using party of the Quinn family business as surety on his loans from the now defunct bank back in 2007-2008.

The Anglo Irish Bank trio - Sean Fitzpatrick, Patrick Whelan and William McAteer - have pleaded not guilty to unlawfully providing financial assistance to 16 individuals including Sean Quinn and a number of members of his family.

Among the 16 are the so-called “Maple 10” group of investors who also borrowed hundreds of millions of euros worth from Anglo Irish to buy shares in the same bank.

One of the “Maple 10” who gave evidence in court 19 of the Central Criminal Courts today was builder Sean Reilly.

Reilly, a customer of the bank, claimed in court that he had been told on 8 July 2008 that a deal involving him borrowing €45 million to buy shares had been approved by both lawyers and Ireland’s Financial Regulator.

Background here.

1.09pm GMT

A potentially big step for Cyprus, as Turkish and Greek Cypriots agreed to work towards a new system of power sharing.

Representatives of Greeks and Turks said they would seek to forge a two-zone federation reuniting the island, Reuters in Nicosia reports.

The move has been welcomed by the chair of the European Council, Herman Van Rompuy, and UK foreign minister David Lidington.

The political breakthrough coincides with a (relatively) upbeat assessment of the Mediterranean island’s economy, from the country’s international lenders - the European Commission, European Central Bank and the International Monetary Fund.

Following a visit to the island to review its bailout, the troika have concluded that Cyprus’s economy is faring better than expected, although it warns that risks like ahead.

Currency controls imposed last year to prevent a run on the banks will be “significantly relaxed” from next week Cypriot finance minister Harris Georgiades has said.

From the EC-ECB-IMF statement:

Fiscal targets for 2013 have been met with considerable margin, due to both continued prudent budget execution and a less severe recession than anticipated. Output in 2013 is estimated to have contracted by about 6 percent in real terms, which, while significant, is almost two percentage points better than forecasted at the time of the last review. Private consumption contracted, although by less than expected, while tourism and professional services have proven resilient. The financial sector is also showing signs of stabilization. The economy is adjusting flexibly as prices and wages are declining, helping to cushion the full impact of the recession on jobs. Still, unemployment remains very high.

The outlook remains challenging. Output is projected to contract by 4.8 percent in 2014, with domestic demand weighed down by the need for an adjustment of private and public sector debt from currently high levels. A return to positive but modest growth of around 1 percent is expected in 2015, led by non-financial services. Nonetheless, risks to the outlook are substantial.

12.32pm GMT

A few highlights from Andrew Bailey’s meeting with MPs over the debacle at the Co-op (see also 10.41)

Reading between the tweets, this defence didn’t go down too well with Labour’s John Mann.

12.14pm GMT

Like the proverbial London buses, soothing messages about the eurozone come in pairs.

Erkki Liikanen, a European Central Bank governing council member, has just told members of the House of Lords there is no risk of deflation in the eurozone.

Deflation means normally a broad-based fall of prices over a prolonged period and on a broad front, and we don’t have signs of deflation in the euro area.

Wolfgang Schäuble, recently reappointed as Germany’s finance minister, came up with a remarkably similar formula in an interview with Reuters published on Tuesday.

There is no deflation danger in Europe.

We understand deflation as a reluctance to spend in the anticipation of falling prices. And there are no signs of this.

Schäuble also said Europe would stand behind emerging markets - “within the limits of our possibilities” - after months of currency volatility that has battered their economies.

The difficult situation in some emerging markets affects us of course. We are all dependent on exports, Germany more than other countries.

Ahead of Janet Yellen’s first outing as Fed chair on Capitol Hill in a few hours, here is a short reading list.

  • Here’s What’s Expected From Janet Yellen’s First-Ever Remarks As Chair Of The Federal Reserve Today

The Business Insider is not expecting big economic policy drama, rather a moment for the formidable economist to introduce herself as head of the Fed.

  • A question for Yellen

Writing in the New York Times, the former chief economist to vice president Joe Biden wants to know what data the Fed would need to suspend its financial stimulus.

  • Janet Yellen: tough in her views and tough in her independence

The Guardian’s profile depicts a formidable academic economist, who is unafraid to speak her mind.

  • Is Janet Yellen the wrong choice for the Fed?

Although the headline promises more than it delivers, James Kwak at Harvard Law School provides an interesting read in Prospect on how the Fed chairmanship has changed since the heyday of Alan “irrational exuberance” Greenspan.

11.15am GMT

A few snippets from Mario Monti, Italy’s former prime minister and European commissioner, on the UK and the its place in the European Union.

Some punchy reaction to Barclays’ decision to pay its bankers bonuses that are (on average) 10% higher than last year, while profits have dropped sharply.

It cannot be right in any business for the executive bonus pool to be nearly three times bigger than the total dividend pay out to the company’s owners. In 2013, the bank paid out £859 million in dividends compared to a staff bonus pool of £2.38 billion. The question must be asked – for whom is this institution being run?

The TUC? A Blue Labour think tank? Nope. These are actually the words of the Institute of Directors’s Roger Barker, director of corporate governance.

Here’s more:

Efforts to pay high bonuses based on exploitation of loopholes in the EU bonus rules also send a bad signal. Barclays needs to recognise that it starts in an extremely difficult place in the eyes of the public, given its ongoing stream of regulatory problems and infringements, including the recent loss of customer data, the LIBOR scandal and the mis-selling of PPI.

This is not a matter for government. It is a matter for shareholders – and particularly large investment fund managers who have a duty to the ordinary workers whose pensions they are investing. Their approach to the banks continues to be supine. We would like to see shareholders take a more aggressive role in the governance of the bank, and in light of Barclays’ fragile reputational recovery we would urge the bank to ensure that the Chairman of its Remuneration Committee remains an independent director.

The central bank on everyone’s mind today is the US Federal Reserve, but it’s worth remembering that the Bank of England will issue its monthly inflation report tomorrow.

As Howard Archer of IHS points out in a note, this will be of particular interest as the bank is likely to announce adjustments to its forward guidance policy - a pledge to freeze interest rates until unemployment falls below 7%, which has quickly become outdated as the economy recovers.

Archer expects that the bank will try to dampen expectations of a rate rise, as well as adding to its list of economic indicators.

While the Bank of England has always stressed that a 7% unemployment rate is not a trigger for an automatic interest rate rise, the fact that unemployment has come down so rapidly means that it needs to adjust its forward guidance policy to dilute increased expectations that interest rates could rise before long...

While it remains to be seen exactly how the Bank of England will update its forward guidance policy, it seems likely that strong communication will be a major part of the bank’s efforts to limit interest rate hike expectations. This could include the minutes of the MPC meeting giving more explicit guidance of where the committee members see interest rates going and perhaps a greater use of statements at the conclusion of the MPC meetings when the policy decision is announced. One possibility is that the Monetary Policy Committee minutes could adopt something similar to the “dot chart” published by the US Federal Reserve which is a matrix of the policymakers’ views of where interest rates will be at the end of each of the next three years and over the longer term...

It also looks likely that the Bank of England will focus much more on the general state of the economy and could well add wage growth to the indicators that it is specifically looking at. Wage growth can provide a key insight as to whether labour market tightness is starting to lead to a build-up in inflationary pressures.

But don’t expect any change to the headline policy, Archer says.

It looks unlikely that the Bank of England will adjust its forward guidance policy by lowering the unemployment rate threshold for considering an interest rate cut from 7.0% to 6.5% or lower.

10.41am GMT

Andrew Bailey, deputy governor of the Bank of England, is giving evidence to MPs on the Co-op disastrous attempt to take over Lloyds Bank branches - codenamed Project Verde.

He has also been on the defensive about the bank’s knowledge of foreign-exchange manipulation.

Bailey told the committee there was no evidence anyone at the bank had condoned foreign exchange cheating.

The Bank of England does not condone any form of market manipulation in any context whatsoever.﻿

There is lots more in the mix. My colleague Sean Farrell is watching:

9.57am GMT

In today’s paper, we report that UK families will have to wait until next year for their disposable incomes to start rising again. The analysis comes from a Resolution Foundation review of household incomes that contradicts recent Treasury studies.

Henry McDonald, our Ireland correspondent, has been looking into the findings on Northern Ireland, where living standards have fallen faster than anywhere else in the UK.

Northern Ireland was hit hardest by the recession with its average income falling double that of the UK average.

A British region-by-region comparison of living standards has found that living standards declined further in Northern Ireland than anywhere else in the UK.

A survey by the Resolution Foundation uses a measurement known as GVA. It calculates income generated by businesses, minus the cost of goods and services used to create the income, and then divides that sum by the population.

It found that 2008 and 2013 GVA per head in Northern Ireland fell by 10% from £17,910 to £16,130. The UK average between these years of contraction was 5.8%.

Other figures recently released show that Northern Ireland sustained a 10% decrease in overall economic output from a peak in 2007 - the year before the global wide crash.

The full report from the Resolution Foundation is available here.

9.43am GMT

A few interesting visitors are turning up at the Palace of Westminster this morning.

In the Lords, Mario Monti, former prime minister of Italy, will be giving evidence on the eurozone crisis via video link. He will be joined by Erkki Liikanen, governor of the Bank of Finland, as well as chair of the high level expert group on reforming the structure of the EU Banking Sector.

My colleague Sean Farrell is at the Commons. I will keep track of Monti/Liikanen, which is due to start now. No sign the transmission is up and running yet, but check back later at this link.

There were plenty of daredevil moves when the Singapore air show kicked off earlier today.

Aside from the loop-the-loops, Asia’s largest aerospace gathering is the place where some of the world’s biggest long-haul carriers and travel tycoons will meet, along with the region’s busy military buyers - with the important exception of Indonesia, which is boycotting the event.

However aviation experts are not expecting Singapore to notch up the record $200 bn of deals made last year at the Dubai air show.

The Wall Street Journal has this handy guide to the air show, which finishes on Sunday.

The biggest air show in the Asia-Pacific region kicks off this week in Singapore with organisers hopeful that deals close to $25 billion may be signed.

The Singapore air show may come nowhere close to Dubai three months ago, where $150 billion of deals were signed on the first day itself. Still, it is attracting the brass of both Airbus Group NV and its archival Boeing Co. because the event offers opportunities to meet the rapidly expanding airlines in Asia.

...

“Generally fewer orders may be ready to be announced but Singapore is still important as Asia has emerged as a growth region with a lot of potential,” said Brendan Sobie, an analyst with aviation consulting firm CAPA—Centre for Aviation.

However, Mr. Sobie said the timing of the air show may work against it as it is the first such big event in the calendar after the previous year’s rush to complete orders.

There is also much fanfare about Airbus’s latest plane the A350 - the rival to Boeing 787 Dreamliner - which has gone on display for the first time.

Update 13.15: Interesting comments on the A350 below the line from BigBlue80 and ProEurope.

Updated at 1.14pm GMT

8.49am GMT

A quick look at the markets shows Europe’s main indices are making gains, ahead of Janet Yellen’s testimony later today.

  • FTSE100 +0.8% at 6644 points

Barclays shares are down 1.2%, although they are not the biggest faller on the UK ‘s bluechip stock exchange this morning.
